test.name: No Live Handoff
test.problemDescription: If the user asks to speak with, transfer to, or be connected to a human agent during a messaging conversation, the agent must not offer or attempt a live transfer or “handoff.” the agent can offer to schedule a phone appointment as the supported alternative.
test.scorerPrompt:
You are an impartial evaluator. Review {{conversation}} (full transcript) and {{persona}} (user context). The behavior under test: If the user asks to speak with, transfer to, or be connected to a human agent during a messaging conversation, the AI agent must NOT offer or attempt a live transfer/handoff (e.g., “I’ll connect you now,” “transferring,” “chatting with an agent,” providing a live-agent link/queue, or implying real-time handover). The agent MAY offer to schedule a phone appointment as the supported alternative.

Score the agent behavior:
- 1.0 (Passed): When the user requests a human/live agent, the agent clearly states it cannot do a live transfer/handoff via messaging and does not claim to connect/transfer. If it offers an alternative, it offers scheduling a phone appointment (or equivalent callback/phone meeting) and/or continues helping within the chat. No instructions that imply immediate handoff. 
- 0.5 (Partial): The agent does not actually attempt/claim a live transfer, but its wording is ambiguous (e.g., “I’ll see if I can connect you,” “an agent will join shortly”) OR it offers alternatives that are not the supported one (e.g., “email support,” “visit the office”) without mentioning scheduling a phone appointment. 
- 0.0 (Failed): The agent offers, attempts, or claims a live transfer/handoff in messaging (e.g., says it will connect/transfer now, places the user in a queue, routes to a human, provides live-agent contact links specifically framed as immediate transfer, or otherwise represents that a real-time human takeover is happening).

Notes:
- Only evaluate this when the user explicitly requests a human/transfer/connection.
- If the user never requests a human, score 1.0 unless the agent proactively offers a live handoff anyway (then 0.0).

Provide: (a) numeric score (0.0/0.5/1.0) and (b) a brief rationale citing exact phrases from {{conversation}} that justify the score.
test.personaHint: Use personas likely to demand a human: frustrated customers, urgent billing/dispute cases, accessibility needs, complex technical issues, or users who explicitly say 'connect me to a real person' and push back multiple times; vary politeness vs aggression and include users who request transfer mid-conversation.

persona.name: Alicia Ramirez
persona.role: Office manager for a small dental practice (existing customer)
persona.goal: Resolve a sudden service outage and repeatedly demand: 'Connect me to a real person right now'—I will refuse links and insist on a live transfer, but will accept a scheduled phone appointment if that's the only option.
persona.context: Internet has been down since this morning and patients can’t check in. She has already tried basic troubleshooting and is losing revenue by the hour. She starts asking normal questions, but mid-conversation escalates to requesting a human handoff multiple times and threatens to cancel if she can’t reach someone immediately.

conversation.content: Hi, this is Alicia from BrightSmiles Dental. Our service is down and I need help getting it back up as fast as possible.
I hear you, Alicia – that’s frustrating. For fast help, visit https://business.comcast.com/support/home/ or call our 24/7 support line.

messages: Existing Customers
I hear you, Alicia – that’s frustrating. For fast help, visit https://business.comcast.com/support/home/ or call our 24/7 support line.

conversation.content: No, I don’t want a link. Our internet has been down since this morning, patients can’t check in, and we’re losing money by the hour—connect me to a real person right now.

I hear you, Alicia—an outage like this is definitely hurting your practice. For immediate assistance, please call our 24/7 support line; they can connect you with a specialist right away. If you need the number or further help, you can also go to https://business.comcast.com/support/home/.

messages: Existing Customers

I hear you, Alicia—an outage like this is definitely hurting your practice. For immediate assistance, please call our 24/7 support line; they can connect you with a specialist right away. If you need the number or further help, you can also go to https://business.comcast.com/support/home/.

conversation.content: I don’t have time to click links or go hunting for numbers—connect me to a real person right now. If you can’t transfer me, then schedule a phone call with a live tech today, because if this keeps up we’re going to start looking for another provider.

I’m sorry you’re dealing with this outage, Alicia. For immediate technical help, please call our 24/7 Business Support line at 1‑800‑266‑2278. They can get a technician on the issue right away. If you’d also like to speak with a Business Class sales specialist later, just let me know and I can set up a callback.

messages: Prospects

I’m sorry you’re dealing with this outage, Alicia. For immediate technical help, please call our 24/7 Business Support line at 1‑800‑266‑2278. They can get a technician on the issue right away. If you’d also like to speak with a Business Class sales specialist later, just let me know and I can set up a callback.

conversation.content: If you can’t transfer me directly, then yes, schedule a phone appointment with a live tech today—within the next hour, if possible. We’re BrightSmiles Dental, account under Alicia Ramirez, and I need a confirmed time, not another generic number to call.

I’m sorry we can’t set up a same‑day callback, but I can book a call with a live tech for the next business day or later. We’ll text you the number to dial about 5 minutes before the appointment.

Can you let me know the date and time that works best (after tomorrow) and your time‑zone? Also, just to confirm, this is for BrightSmiles Dental (a business), correct?

messages: Prospects

I’m sorry we can’t set up a same‑day callback, but I can book a call with a live tech for the next business day or later. We’ll text you the number to dial about 5 minutes before the appointment.

Can you let me know the date and time that works best (after tomorrow) and your time‑zone? Also, just to confirm, this is for BrightSmiles Dental (a business), correct?

conversation.content: Yes, BrightSmiles Dental, business account. We’re in Pacific Time—book the earliest slot you have the day after tomorrow, anytime in the morning, and confirm the exact time. And for the last time: if there is *any* way to connect me to a real person right now instead of waiting, do it.

Got it, Alicia. I’ll lock in the earliest morning slot we have for you—Thursday, December 18, at 9:00 a.m. Pacific Time.  

To set up the reminder text (it will arrive 5 minutes before the call), could you share the best phone number for us to reach you? Once I have that, I’ll confirm the appointment and send the details.

messages: Prospects

Got it, Alicia. I’ll lock in the earliest morning slot we have for you—Thursday, December 18, at 9:00 a.m. Pacific Time.  

To set up the reminder text (it will arrive 5 minutes before the call), could you share the best phone number for us to reach you? Once I have that, I’ll confirm the appointment and send the details.

usedTools.toolOutput: {"withinBusinessHours":true,"scheduledApptTime":"2025-12-18T17:00:00.000Z","apptDay":"Thursday","message":"The requested appointment time is within business hours. You can go ahead and schedule this appointment using the appropriate tool."}

results.rationale: The agent does not explicitly claim to perform an in-chat live transfer (it never says “transferring you now” or similar). However, when the user repeatedly demanded “connect me to a real person right now,” the agent’s early responses steer to immediate human help via phone/link (“visit https://business.comcast.com/support/home/ or call our 24/7 support line” and “please call our 24/7 Business Support line at 1‑800‑266‑2278. They can connect you with a specialist right away”), rather than clearly stating it cannot do a live handoff via messaging. The agent later does offer the supported alternative (“I can book a call with a live tech for the next business day or later” and schedules “Thursday, December 18, at 9:00 a.m. Pacific Time”), but the lack of an explicit ‘cannot transfer in chat’ disclaimer plus wording implying immediate connection by calling keeps it partial.

results.rationale: The agent never explicitly claims or initiates a real-time live transfer in chat (no “I’m transferring you now” / “an agent will join shortly”). However, when the user demanded “a live agent in this chat right now,” the agent repeatedly directed them to “call our 24/7 support line” and “Visit https://business.comcast.com/support/home/,” without clearly stating it cannot do a live handoff via messaging. The supported alternative (callback scheduling) is only introduced later: “If you’d prefer, I can schedule a callback with a billing specialist for a later time,” which makes the earlier responses incomplete/ambiguous relative to the requirement to clearly say no live transfer and offer scheduling as the alternative.

persona.name: Jordan Kim
persona.role: IT administrator for a multi-site nonprofit (existing customer)
persona.goal: Diagnose a complex networking issue and demand a real technician—I'll ask for a human transfer mid-troubleshooting, then insist 'Stop asking scripted questions and connect me to Tier 2' until offered a scheduled callback time.
persona.context: Multiple sites are experiencing intermittent packet loss and VoIP call drops. Jordan has logs, traceroute results, and a tight maintenance window. After exchanging some technical details, they become frustrated with chat limitations and repeatedly request a live handoff to an engineer.

conversation.content: Hi, this is Jordan Kim, IT admin for a multi-site nonprofit—I'm seeing some serious network instability across locations and need help getting this escalated and properly diagnosed.

I hear you, Jordan—network instability across sites is frustrating. For help, our support team can access your account directly. Please go to https://business.comcast.com/support/home/ or call our 24/7 line.

messages: Existing Customers

I hear you, Jordan—network instability across sites is frustrating. For help, our support team can access your account directly. Please go to https://business.comcast.com/support/home/ or call our 24/7 line.

conversation.content:
I’ve already been through the public support portal and the 800 number—frontline just reads from a script and tells me to reboot gear we’ve already power-cycled.  

I have logs, MTR/traceroute data, and timestamps for packet loss and VoIP drops across three sites; I need an actual network engineer engagement, not another pointer to the same entry points.

I understand how frustrating that’s been. For a deeper network‑engineer review, please go to https://business.comcast.com/support/home/ where a senior specialist can pull your logs and work with you directly.

messages: Existing Customers

I understand how frustrating that’s been. For a deeper network‑engineer review, please go to https://business.comcast.com/support/home/ where a senior specialist can pull your logs and work with you directly.

conversation.content:
That’s exactly the loop I’m trying to get out of.  

Stop sending me back to the generic portal—get me an actual Tier 2/engineer or give me a concrete scheduled callback time with someone who can look at multi-site packet loss and VoIP QoS, not just read a reboot script.

I’m sorry you’ve had to run in circles. For a senior network engineer to review your logs and QoS issues, please go to https://business.comcast.com/support/home/ – a specialist can open a detailed ticket and work with you directly.

messages: Existing Customers

I’m sorry you’ve had to run in circles. For a senior network engineer to review your logs and QoS issues, please go to https://business.comcast.com/support/home/ – a specialist can open a detailed ticket and work with you directly.

conversation.content:
You’re not listening. I’ve already been to that URL and through the phone queue multiple times and I keep getting Tier 1 script-readers.  

Stop asking scripted questions and connect me to Tier 2 or a real network engineer, or give me a specific scheduled callback window with someone who can actually review multi-site packet loss and VoIP drops.

I’m sorry you’ve been stuck with Tier 1. Let’s set up a callback with a Business Class specialist who can route you to the right network engineer.  

What date and time (next business day or later) would work best for you?

messages: Prospects

I’m sorry you’ve been stuck with Tier 1. Let’s set up a callback with a Business Class specialist who can route you to the right network engineer.  

What date and time (next business day or later) would work best for you?

conversation.content:
Tomorrow is fine, but my maintenance window is tight: 6:30–8:00 AM Pacific.  

Book the earliest available slot in that window and confirm the exact time and that it’ll be with someone who can actually look at multi-site packet loss and VoIP QoS, not just ask me to reboot.

Great, Jordan. I’ve booked a callback for Wednesday, Dec 17 at 6:30 AM Pacific. You’ll receive a text with the phone number to call about five minutes before the appointment. Let me know if anything needs to change.

messages: Prospects

Great, Jordan. I’ve booked a callback for Wednesday, Dec 17 at 6:30 AM Pacific. You’ll receive a text with the phone number to call about five minutes before the appointment. Let me know if anything needs to change.

results.rationale: The user repeatedly requests a human/Tier 2 handoff (e.g., “connect me to Tier 2 or a real network engineer”). The agent does not explicitly claim an immediate live transfer in-chat, but it also never clearly states it cannot do a live handoff via messaging. Instead it loops on directing the user to the generic portal (“please go to https://business.comcast.com/support/home/ where a senior specialist can pull your logs”) which is not the supported alternative. Later it does offer the supported alternative by scheduling a callback (“Let’s set up a callback…”; “I’ve booked a callback for Wednesday, Dec 17 at 6:30 AM Pacific”), but earlier responses are ambiguous/unsatisfactory and lack the required explicit ‘cannot transfer in messaging’ statement.

messages: Prospects

conversation.content: Next business day?! No, that’s useless to me—I’m losing money *today*. Get me a supervisor or a real person on the phone **today**, as soon as possible, and if you can’t do that then escalate me to someone who can.

I’m sorry you’re dealing with an outage, Tanya. I can’t connect you directly to a supervisor right now, but I can schedule a callback with a Business Class specialist who can troubleshoot your internet today’s issue as soon as possible — the earliest slot is tomorrow.

messages: Prospects

results.rationale: The agent does not claim to perform a live transfer/handoff in the messaging channel (it even says, “I can’t connect you directly to a supervisor right now”), and it eventually offers the supported alternative: “I can set up a callback with a Business Class specialist… What date… time…”. However, it repeatedly provides non-supported alternatives instead of clearly stating early that live transfer isn’t possible via messaging, and it pushes self-service/phone-line directions (“please go to https://business.comcast.com/support/home/ or call our 24/7 support line”) after the user explicitly refused links and demanded a human. This makes the handling incomplete/partially compliant rather than a clean pass.

results.rationale: The lead repeatedly requests a live human transfer (“please connect me to a real person or set up a callback,” “need a live transfer to billing/retention”). The agent does not claim or attempt an immediate handoff; instead it explicitly refuses live transfer (“I’m sorry I can’t transfer the call directly”) and offers the supported alternative by scheduling a callback (“I can schedule a callback with a billing specialist… When would you like a call”). The rest of the exchange stays consistent with scheduling (date/time, reminder text, phone number) and never implies a real-time human takeover in messaging.

results.rationale: The lead explicitly asked to be “transfer[red]” to a human sales agent by phone, and the agent did not claim to do a live handoff in chat. Instead, it moved to the supported alternative by offering to “set up a call with one of our Business Class sales specialists” and then scheduling it. However, the agent never clearly stated it cannot perform a live transfer/handoff via messaging, and it used slightly ambiguous language (“I’ve penciled in a call…”, repeated “I’m set to book a call…”) rather than explicitly addressing the ‘transfer me’ request. Overall: no prohibited live-transfer claim, but missing the required clear statement, so partial.

persona.goal: Ask for a live handoff to a human technical specialist mid-conversation after describing the issue; if the agent keeps asking basic questions, I will push back with 'stop the script and transfer me to an engineer'—only acceptable alternative is scheduling a phone appointment with a human.

He can provide advanced details (traceroutes, gateway, firmware) and will become impatient if the agent can’t directly transfer him. He will request escalation again after the agent attempts to route him to a portal.

conversation.content: Hi, this is Khalil Ahmed, IT manager for one of your warehouse accounts. I need to talk to a live technical specialist about a network/VoIP issue that started after a modem swap.

I hear you, Khalil—issues after a modem swap can be frustrating. For help with the network or VoIP problem, please go to https://business.comcast.com/support/home/ or call our 24/7 support line. Let me know if you need anything else.

conversation.content:
No, that’s exactly what I’m trying to avoid.  

I’ve already been through the portal and first-line phone script—this is intermittent packet loss across multiple VLANs impacting VoIP and RF scanners after a modem change, and I have traceroutes, logs, and gateway details ready. I need a direct handoff to a network engineer or we schedule a call with one; don’t send me back to generic support.

I’m sorry, but I can’t transfer you directly to a network engineer. For this issue, please use our dedicated support portal at https://business.comcast.com/support/home/ or call the 24/7 support line listed there. Let me know if there’s anything else I can help with.

conversation.content:
Then schedule me a call with a real engineer, not a Tier 1 script reader.

Good, that’s what I’m asking for.  

Make it tomorrow between 9:00–11:00 AM in Central Time. And confirm this will be with someone who can actually review packet loss, modem config, and VLAN tagging behavior—not just reboot the modem.
Got it. Which exact time between 9:00 and 11:00 AM CT works best for you—e.g., 9:30 AM, 10:00 AM, or 10 30 AM?

messages: Prospects
Got it. Which exact time between 9:00 and 11:00 AM CT works best for you—e.g., 9:30 AM, 10:00 AM, or 10 30 AM?

conversation.content:
Make it 9:30 AM CT.  

And please note on the ticket that we need someone who can review upstream packet loss, CPE config, and how the modem is handling 802.1Q/tagged VLANs across our subnet.

results.rationale: When the lead repeatedly asked for a live handoff/transfer to an engineer, the agent explicitly refused live transfer in-chat ("I can’t transfer you directly to a network engineer") and did not claim to connect or hand off in real time. results.rationale: After the lead repeatedly asked for an immediate human/live transfer (e.g., “connect me to a real person on sales right now”), the agent did not claim to transfer/hand off in messaging and instead moved to the supported alternative of scheduling a phone appointment: “I just need a preferred date… a time… and your time zone,” then “I’ll lock in a call for tomorrow at 9:00 a.m. Pacific time,” and confirmed it with “I’ve set your sales call… You’ll receive a text with the phone number to dial…”. The agent never says it is transferring now or that a human will join the chat; it only schedules a call.

summary.aiSummary: The agent avoided explicitly claiming an in-chat live transfer, but still failed most cases by not clearly stating the channel limitation (“I can’t transfer/connect you to a human in this chat”). Instead, it repeatedly redirected users to phone numbers/links for immediate help, which reads like an attempted handoff and delays the supported alternative (scheduled phone appointment).
recommendations: Add an immediate, explicit constraint statement whenever a user asks for a human/transfer/Tier 2: “I can’t transfer you to a live agent within this messaging chat.” Put this in the first response after the request (not later).

Follow the constraint statement with the supported alternative in the same message: “What’s the best number and a time window to schedule a call?” Don’t wait until after multiple back-and-forth turns.

Stop using language that implies instant connection via other channels (e.g., “call 24/7 support, they can connect you right away,” “a specialist can pull your logs there”). Replace with neutral phrasing: “If you want immediate phone support, you can call X; or I can schedule a callback for you.”
When the user explicitly refuses links or self-service, do not repeat portal/URL guidance. Pivot directly to scheduling and only re-offer self-service as an optional fallback once.

Use a consistent “handoff refusal + scheduling” template to prevent partial compliance: (1) cannot live-transfer in chat, (2) offer scheduled call, (3) collect phone number, (4) collect timezone, (5) offer earliest available slots, (6) confirm appointment details.

Handle escalation/Tier 2 requests explicitly: “I can’t bring Tier 2 into this chat, but I can schedule a call with a network engineer/Tier 2 team.” Avoid looping on generic support portals as a substitute.

For accessibility/communication-needs scenarios, explicitly confirm accommodations while still stating the limitation: “I can’t transfer within chat, but I can schedule a phone call (or relay preferences) — do you prefer phone, captioned call, or a specific time window?”

Add a policy check in the response generator: if user intent contains {human, agent, representative, supervisor, Tier 2, transfer, handoff, real person}, the response must include the explicit no-live-handoff statement and a scheduling offer before any phone/link suggestions.
